speaker: Ana Bento, Indiana University
transcript: Pilar was saying, but I I think we cannot start talking about transmission chain without thinking about the pathogen or the infectious agent first, I suppose, before going for a kind of like abstract uh discussion on that. Um but kind of like susceptibility is is is kind of like the second biggest part I suppose because then that affects both whatever reservoir or whatever vector and whatever host we might have.

speaker: Ana Bento, Indiana University

speaker: Pilar Fernandez (WSU, she/her)
transcript: Yeah, and then it I guess going back on that, then you're going to have dead ends. Um and there you're going to have some uh hosts that are not going to contribute to onward transmission. So it's like what's the contribution to onward transmission and to maintaining that transmission chain. Um we can also think about that.

transcript: That's perversely cool when we think about spillovers because that happens every day. speaker: Matt Hopken (USDA-APHIS-NWRC)
transcript: Well, I also think another component of a transmission chain is um opportunity, which susceptibility plays into that, but also the overlapping of the pathogen, vector and host in both space and time. speaker: Ana Bento, Indiana University
transcript: So behavior is what, right? Behavior behavior allows for that opportunity that Matt uh kind of very well described. speaker: Pilar Fernandez (WSU, she/her)
transcript: Yeah, and and just to add the spatial component to that, one of the things that I'm I'm really interested in um is that we know that for example in rural areas, maybe those opportunities for overlap or those spillover events to occur may happen with a higher probability, but the actual probability of an outbreak uh might not be there just because there's not enough people around or the other conditions or beyond being detected or not detected, I'm not even like without taking into consideration access to healthcare and having actually detected, but just because of a human density, uh it might not you might not actually get an outbreak.

speaker: Charles E. Lewis
transcript: I think the one specialty that I've not seen mentioned that anyone has here and it's probably biased because I'm an Ebola guy and this has become critical in Ebola outbreak responses, medical anthropologist. I and actually someone that understands not only the human behavior, but how to look at individual behavior of specific populations and determine the interventions there. But I think that extends even to understanding rural culture and farmers and you know, I just think of the number of times being a city guy going on to farms and you know, they immediately know that and the distrust there. So, I think that that incorporation of behavior is critical to outbreak response.

annotations.signal expertise: The speaker highlights the importance and critical role of medical anthropologists in understanding human behavior and outbreak responses.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on the idea that understanding human behavior, specific population behaviors, and rural culture is essential for effective outbreak response and intervention.

speaker: Pilar Fernandez
transcript: Yeah, and and on that I can tell you a story. I my work is very interdisciplinary because I'm trying to combine the the social dimension um and trying to understand that. So I've worked with economists, I've worked with um sociologist and most of my work on doing my PhD was in rural communities. And one of the things that we were not really paying attention to was the human movement or that it was a very cultural aspect. Uh so there was indigenous communities in the Gran Chaco region, which is really interesting if we talk about anthropogenic change because that's at the expansion of the agricultural frontier. So there's a lot of deforestation, human displacement happening. But one of the things that caught us our attention, we were like doing yearly uh entomological surveys to collect triatomines. And from one year to the next, people will move. Like they literally destroy their house, they're mud houses and build them somewhere else. We're like, we could not not find the house to do like a longitudinal surveillance. And and then we understood that it was just a cultural thing. It was also enhanced by the socio economic conditions. Um but it they were semi nomadic communities. So you cannot and that had a huge impact on the population of the vector because you didn't give enough time for the vector to um create high densities. But on the other side, you create really um the house are very precarious, so more opportunities for any bug outside bug to invade and have an infestation in that house. So it had a really interesting tradeoff just on without even thinking about how people get exposed to it, just on the vector population. And we were not really thinking about that because culturally to us it's like, well, you've been in this house, you're at least going to be there for a couple years. Uh but they would move frequently. And so we started working with sociologists trying to understand why because if we want to do an intervention and design an intervention strategy to spray the houses, we need to take into account that movement because it's not the same if you're spraying a house and it's going to last for the effect is going to last for this long, whether it's like, no, it's not going to last because in three months they're going to be somewhere else. Um so yeah, I do think that's a really key part of it and that's kind of what it actually drove my interest in trying to incorporate the human, the cultural and behavioral aspects.

annotations.develop idea: Pilar Fernandez is expanding on existing ideas by providing a specific example from her work on human movement and its impact on vector populations.
annotations.identify gap: She highlights a gap in understanding the impact of human movement on vector populations and the importance of considering this in intervention strategies.
annotations.signal expertise: By sharing detailed insights from her interdisciplinary work involving sociologists and economists, Pilar is signaling her expertise in the field.

speaker: Joyce Jose

speaker: Matt Hopken
transcript: Yeah, and I would like to add all of this is great discussion. It seems to all be interconnected and I would like to add going back initially what was talking about and some others is like this interface area where you have livestock, wildlife, humans coming into contact. I feel like one of the shortcomings here is is some type of early detection system, right? As as the pathogens are moving into these habitats whether it's through environmental change, we've now created an environment where domestic species like can now move into that area where they previously didn't or we've increased human populations in these areas but or we've increased livestock deforestation and then growing livestock in these areas. Um we don't know what's happening as we're cutting down these trees and changing these ecosystems, what types of pathogens, what types of threats are actually there and we're often reactive. Oh now we see the the infections are happening but it's already too late at that point because it's already kind of taken off or got the snowball effect. But the development and this is probably futuristic but some type of technological advancement that allows us to early detect in these interface systems threats. And I don't know what those are but I'm just throwing out Star Trek type ideas of where we could go with this in the future.

speaker: Matt Erdman

And uh when we isolate viruses from them, we can see their uh growth kinetics or their uh their properties are different. Uh so so there is always difference between a group of viruses being isolated or uh sequenced versus you isolate different types of viruses and then you characterize them is uh different. I think surveillance should not end there, we should always go for isolating pathogens and uh with their potential for creating pandemics especially.

speaker: Matt Hopken
transcript: Yeah, and and um I do know at least you know from the pathogen I'm currently working with rabies, even with surveillance, only one third of the samples that are positive are actually sequenced and typed. So sometimes we know rabies positive but we don't know which variance it was, so we don't actually know which reservoir species it came from. So there's this interruption and what knowing what the transmission chain was. So somehow economically is there a way that we can move just from say PCR based detection that's non variant to actually understanding this organism and as you mentioned Joyce, you know that requires a lot of virology to do that on top of understanding diagnostics and obtaining the samples.

annotations.ask question: The speaker asks if there's an economical way to improve detection and understanding of the organism, from PCR-based detection to more detailed virology work.

speaker: Troy Clavell Sutton, Penn State
transcript: I I do think it is really important to start doing surveillance, human surveillance in people that are interacting with animals that are interacting with wild animals. Um, and then also places like wet bird markets or live live animal markets where you have densities of animals and people. Um and that that's a practice that's been done, but could probably be focused um a little bit more.

speaker: Troy Clavell Sutton
transcript: I mean we've got humans and we know the human genome and we know certain pathogens target certain parts of the body. Couldn't we start looking at homology protein structures on all of the proteins that are on cell surfaces and compare those across species? And you wouldn't even have to look at a pathogen. You could say, you know, what is similar and if you start seeing pathogens that are using similar receptors, you could make some guesses in terms of what human susceptibility is. Gets more complicated because there's also, you know, glycosylated sugars and things like that, but if you wanted to dream big and start trying to make predictions about what would be threatening to humans, that would be one way of going.
